In a story written in this language, a character convinces himself he must have hallucinated his wife committing adultery. Detectives who speak English and this language investigate a cardboard chess board found next to a dead body in a novel that is set in Alaska by Michael Chabon (“SHAY-bon”). This language, used to write the original The Magician of (*) Lublin, was used for a story in which the Spirit of Evil tempts a baker to urinate in his dough. For 10 points, Isaac Singer’s story “Gimpel the Fool” was written in what language used for stories about Tevye the Milkman, which inspired Fiddler on the Roof?
tossups.question_sanitized: In a novel originally written in this language, a failed robbery leads an artist to seal himself into a house with bricks. In a story written in this language, a character convinces himself he must have hallucinated his wife committing adultery. Detectives who speak English and this language investigate a cardboard chess board found next to a dead body in a novel that is set in Alaska by Michael Chabon ("SHAY-bon"). This language, used to write the original The Magician of (*) Lublin, was used for a story in which the Spirit of Evil tempts a baker to urinate in his dough. For 10 points, Isaac Singer's story "Gimpel the Fool" was written in what language used for stories about Tevye the Milkman, which inspired Fiddler on the Roof?
tossups.answer: Yiddish [accept The Yiddish Policemen’s Union; reject “Hebrew”]
tossups.answer_sanitized: Yiddish [accept The Yiddish Policemen's Union; reject "Hebrew"]

tossups.question: In a story by this author, a character thinks “the whole world is growing smaller every day” before being told “You only need to change your direction” and getting eaten by a cat. This author of “A Little Fable” wrote that “the Sirens have a still more fatal weapon than their song, namely their silence.” In a fable by this author, a dying man is told that a door was only for him after a (*) gatekeeper refuses him entrance. In a short story by this author, a man sits in a cage with straw for forty days of fasting before he dies. In a novel by this author of “A Hunger Artist,” a man is told the parable “Before the Law” before being taken to a quarry and shot “like a dog.” For 10 points, name this author who featured Josef K. in the novel The Trial.
tossups.question_sanitized: In a story by this author, a character thinks "the whole world is growing smaller every day" before being told "You only need to change your direction" and getting eaten by a cat. This author of "A Little Fable" wrote that "the Sirens have a still more fatal weapon than their song, namely their silence." In a fable by this author, a dying man is told that a door was only for him after a (*) gatekeeper refuses him entrance. In a short story by this author, a man sits in a cage with straw for forty days of fasting before he dies. In a novel by this author of "A Hunger Artist," a man is told the parable "Before the Law" before being taken to a quarry and shot "like a dog." For 10 points, name this author who featured Josef K. in the novel The Trial.
tossups.answer: Franz Kafka
tossups.answer_sanitized: Franz Kafka

tossups.question: An artist in this city declares “I don’t want to be a tree, I want to be its meaning.” Armanoush visits the tattoo artist Asya in a 2006 novel titled for a “Bastard of [this city].” A story about an artist in this city staring into the horizon to avoid blindness is told to a bookbinder by Olive. An author collected cigarette butts and salt shakers in this city to replicate a fictional (*) oddities collection inspired by the girl Füsun. The Museum of Innocence is set in this city, as is a novel narrated partly by the corpse of a murdered miniaturist who is the uncle of a man named Black. For 10 points, Orhan Pamuk’s novel My Name is Red is set in what Turkish city?
tossups.question_sanitized: An artist in this city declares "I don't want to be a tree, I want to be its meaning." The Museum of Innocence is set in this city, as is a novel narrated partly by the corpse of a murdered miniaturist who is the uncle of a man named Black. For 10 points, Orhan Pamuk's novel My Name is Red is set in what Turkish city?
tossups.answer: Istanbul [accept Constantinople or Konstantiniyye; accept The Bastard of Istanbul] (The Bastard of Istanbul is by Elif Shafak.)
tossups.answer_sanitized: Istanbul [accept Constantinople or Konstantiniyye; accept The Bastard of Istanbul] (The Bastard of Istanbul is by Elif Shafak.)

tossups.question: The author of this series started writing it around the time he wrote An Evening with Margaret Mead, inspired by the possibility of art as explored in his autobiographical work How I Learned What I Learned. This series’s characters include a harmonica player called both Canewell and Stool Pigeon and a healer who dies at age 366 called Aunt Ester. Gem of the Ocean and (*) Radio Golf bookend this series, whose ten entries are each set in a different decade of the 20th century. In an entry in this series, a potential football scholarship sparks a disagreement between Cory and Troy Maxson. For 10 points, Fences is in what series of plays by August Wilson, largely set in a Pennsylvania city?
tossups.question_sanitized: The author of this series started writing it around the time he wrote An Evening with Margaret Mead, inspired by the possibility of art as explored in his autobiographical work How I Learned What I Learned. This series's characters include a harmonica player called both Canewell and Stool Pigeon and a healer who dies at age 366 called Aunt Ester. In an entry in this series, a potential football scholarship sparks a disagreement between Cory and Troy Maxson. For 10 points, Fences is in what series of plays by August Wilson, largely set in a Pennsylvania city?
tossups.answer: Pittsburgh Cycle [accept American Century Cycle before “century”; accept the August Wilson Century Cycle before “Wilson”]
tossups.answer_sanitized: Pittsburgh Cycle [accept American Century Cycle before "century"; accept the August Wilson Century Cycle before "Wilson"]

tossups.question: This poet contrasted Grishkin, who distills “a feline smell,” with John Webster, who “saw the skull beneath the skin.” This poet wrote that a new work of art modifies “existing monuments” in an essay advocating for authors to learn literary history. A reference to Shakespeare in the line “The Chair she sat in, like a burnished throne” appears in one of this author’s (*) footnotes. That poem by this author quotes Baudelaire in its description of an “Unreal City under the brown fog of a winter dawn.” This poet repeated the Sanskrit word “shantih” to end the “What the Thunder Said” section of a poem he dedicated to Ezra Pound. For 10 points, name this modernist poet of “The Waste Land.”
tossups.question_sanitized: This poet contrasted Grishkin, who distills "a feline smell," with John Webster, who "saw the skull beneath the skin." This poet wrote that a new work of art modifies "existing monuments" in an essay advocating for authors to learn literary history. A reference to Shakespeare in the line "The Chair she sat in, like a burnished throne" appears in one of this author's (*) footnotes. That poem by this author quotes Baudelaire in its description of an "Unreal City under the brown fog of a winter dawn." This poet repeated the Sanskrit word "shantih" to end the "What the Thunder Said" section of a poem he dedicated to Ezra Pound. For 10 points, name this modernist poet of "The Waste Land."
tossups.answer: T. S. Eliot (The unnamed works are “Whispers of Immortality” and “Tradition and the Individual Talent.”)
tossups.answer_sanitized: T. S. Eliot (The unnamed works are "Whispers of Immortality" and "Tradition and the Individual Talent.")

tossups.question: A play by this author ends with a voice calling “he is the God of Love” as a man dies in an avalanche. Another play by this author ends with the Button Molder stating “We meet at the final crossroads” as the protagonist is cradled by Solveig (“sool-VAY”). Another play by this author ends with a man being called “the one cock in the basket” and declaring “people don’t (*) do such things!” One play by this author of Brand ends with a man asking “The most wonderful thing of all?” In a play by this author, George Tesman’s wife shoots herself in the head offstage. A play by this author ends with a door slamming as Nora Helmer leaves her husband. For 10 points, what Norwegian playwright of Peer Gynt wrote Hedda Gabler and A Doll’s House?
tossups.question_sanitized: A play by this author ends with a voice calling "he is the God of Love" as a man dies in an avalanche. Another play by this author ends with a man being called "the one cock in the basket" and declaring "people don't (*) do such things!" One play by this author of Brand ends with a man asking "The most wonderful thing of all?" In a play by this author, George Tesman's wife shoots herself in the head offstage. A play by this author ends with a door slamming as Nora Helmer leaves her husband. For 10 points, what Norwegian playwright of Peer Gynt wrote Hedda Gabler and A Doll's House?
tossups.answer: Henrik Ibsen [or Henrik Johan Ibsen]
tossups.answer_sanitized: Henrik Ibsen [or Henrik Johan Ibsen]

tossups.question: A passage by this author describes how a writer who “draws the world” finds that he has drawn his own face by the end of his life. A review by this real-life author lauds the choice to purposely give the incorrect solution to a murder mystery by Herbert Quain. This author attacked the heretical viewpoints of Nils Runeberg, including a hypothesis that God was Judas. This author described an attempt to recreate (*) Don Quixote line-by-line by his friend Pierre Menard. This author described an incomplete novel that took the form of a physical labyrinth representing all possible futures. For 10 points, name this author who used fictional criticism in works like “The Garden of Forking Paths.”
tossups.question_sanitized: A passage by this author describes how a writer who "draws the world" finds that he has drawn his own face by the end of his life. A review by this real-life author lauds the choice to purposely give the incorrect solution to a murder mystery by Herbert Quain. This author attacked the heretical viewpoints of Nils Runeberg, including a hypothesis that God was Judas. This author described an attempt to recreate (*) Don Quixote line-by-line by his friend Pierre Menard. This author described an incomplete novel that took the form of a physical labyrinth representing all possible futures. For 10 points, name this author who used fictional criticism in works like "The Garden of Forking Paths."
tossups.answer: Jorge Luis Borges [or Jorge Francisco Isidoro Luis Borges Acevedo]
tossups.answer_sanitized: Jorge Luis Borges [or Jorge Francisco Isidoro Luis Borges Acevedo]
